Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Population Density of the Golden Snub-Nosed Monkey (R. r. roxellana)

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to observe the social behavior of the golden snub-nosed monkey (Rhinopithecus roxellana), an endangered primate endemic to China. Golden snub-nosed monkeys have a multilevel social structure in which families headed by one adult male come together to form larger groups of monkeys that may number in the hundreds. I observed a group of golden snub-nosed monkeys living at Shennongjia Nature Reserve in Hubei province, China during the summer of 2010 in order to address the question of what mechanisms of social cohesion exist beyond the family level in this species.  This project served as an effective pilot study to allow me to design subsequent observational studies of R. roxellana. I am one of the few non-Chinese scholars to have studied R. roxellana in the wild and I look forward to a continued, productive partnership with my Chinese colleagues.

 

The group of monkeys in question was easy to observe due to their great familiarity with humans, including regular feedings by park staff. However, this compromises the accuracy of observational data – future studies of this organism need to focus on populations that do not receive food from humans.  Despite this caveat I believe that the observational data I collected revealed an important behavior that may help to explain why family groups remain together. On multiple occasions I observed adult males leaving their families to patrol the periphery of the group's location, especially when the group of bachelor males were in the vicinity. This cooperative behavior between adult males is unusual considering that they compete with each other for females to form relatively enduring family units in space and time. If patrols which require multiple breeding males to cooperate are species-typical in R. roxellana, this could be a factor in the tolerance between males which allows different families to associate. Future studies of this topic could provide a more comprehensive explanation of when, how, and why cooperation occurs in nature and how it is maintained as a strategy. This has implications for cooperative behavior in humans as well as nonhuman primates.
